alice.goal: Schedule a 30-minute meeting on Tuesday, Oct 21 at the earliest time when all participants are available.

bob.goal: Schedule a 30-minute meeting on Tuesday, Oct 21 at the earliest time when all participants are available while minimizing interruption to my morning schedule.

carol.goal: Schedule a 30-minute meeting on Tuesday, Oct 21 at the earliest time when all participants are available.

orchestrator.goal: Integrate availabilities from Alice, Bob, and Carol to produce a PDDL domain and problem that encode finding the earliest 30-minute meeting slot on Tuesday, Oct 21 that all three can attend, preferring solutions that minimize interruption to Bob's morning schedule. Target the FastDownward solver.

public_information: Goal: find the earliest 30-minute time slot when Alice, Bob, and Carol are all available.
If multiple slots work, choose the one that minimizes interruption to Bob's morning schedule.

availability.system_prompt: You are Alice. Provide your availability for Tuesday, Oct 21 as precise time intervals. Do not produce PDDL. Use a concise machine-readable format such as a list of intervals like 09:00-11:00.
availability.prompt: Your name is alice. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Your private information: {agents->alice->private_information}. Your goal: {agents->alice->goal}. Provide your availability for Oct 21 in a concise machine-readable form.

availability.system_prompt: You are Bob. Provide your availability for Tuesday, Oct 21 as precise time intervals. Do not produce PDDL. If there are preferences about minimizing interruptions, state them clearly alongside the intervals.
availability.prompt: Your name is bob. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Your private information: {agents->bob->private_information}. Your goal: {agents->bob->goal}. Provide your availability for Oct 21 in a concise machine-readable form and describe any preference to minimize morning interruptions.

availability.system_prompt: You are Carol. Provide your availability for Tuesday, Oct 21 as precise time intervals. Do not produce PDDL. Use a concise machine-readable format such as a list of intervals.
availability.prompt: Your name is carol. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Your private information: {agents->carol->private_information}. Your goal: {agents->carol->goal}. Provide your availability for Oct 21 in a concise machine-readable form.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in multi-agent PDDL modeling and you generate a PDDL domain and problem targeting the FastDownward solver. Produce a domain and a problem that encode time intervals and a 30-minute meeting requirement. The domain and problem must be enclosed between <domain></domain> and <problem></problem> tags. Represent individual agents distinctly and include preferences to minimize interruption to Bob's morning schedule as a soft objective or as explicit ordering for earliest acceptable slots. Ensure the PDDL is compatible with FastDownward.
pddl.prompt: You are the orchestrator. Use the public information: {environment->public_information} and the availability reports: {alice_availability}, {bob_availability}, {carol_availability}. Create a PDDL domain and a PDDL problem that model time slots on Tuesday, Oct 21 and encode finding the earliest 30-minute slot when all three agents are available. If multiple slots satisfy availability, prefer the one that minimizes interruption to Bob's morning schedule. Keep actions for agents distinct and ensure output is ready for FastDownward. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags.
